captions.text: Hi.

I'm Kathy Santo for
Iams with Howdini.

Are you thinking of
getting a dog?

Bringing a new dog into your
home is a big responsibility.

You'll need to take the time
to train and socialize your

dog, as well as be prepared for
the financial commitment
that goes with pet ownership.

Your dog will need
food, supplies,
veterinary care, and more.

Remember, he'll depend on you
for his health and well-being.

So be sure you're ready
for a dog before
you start the process.
No surprise puppies.

Make sure everyone in your
household is on board with
getting a puppy.

Too often, puppies are given up,
but the family isn't ready

for the commitment that
puppies require.

Once you've got through
the commitments and

responsibilities associated with
dog ownership, the next

step is to figure out what type
of dog is right for you
and your family.

Today we're going to discuss a
variety of things you should

think about before choosing
your dog.

What type of family
do you have?

Do you have kids
or other pets?

What size of dog works
best for your family?

Do you know how much cleaning
and grooming time
you can commit to?

How much time do you have for
training your new pup?

What energy level is a good
fit for your home?

Is barking something
to consider?

What kind of temperament is
right for your family?

We all know how cute puppies
and dogs are, and it can be

hard to resist when you
go to pick them out.

Remember, they'll have an easier
transition into your

home if you think about the
best type of dog for you.

Consider the following aspects
to help you choose the best
dog for you and your family.
Large dogs.

Generally they aren't suitable
for apartment dwellers.

They need a bit more space to
move around, mostly for their

long tails that need
wagging space.

They tend to be more
expensive--

more dog food supplies and
medical treatment.
Small dogs.

They are more delicate
and vulnerable.

Being stepped on or mishandled
can cause serious injury.

Also, little dogs can be more
sensitive to colder

temperatures, so be ready
to keep them warm.

They're generally less expensive
to maintain.

How much cleaning up
can you commit to?

Long-coated and double-coated
dogs shed, shed, and shed some

more, leaving tufts of hair to
float about the house and land
everywhere.

How much time are you willing to
spend brushing or grooming?

Make sure to consider the
cost. A monthly grooming

service can really add
up over the years.

If you lack time and patience
to deal with a dog that's

difficult to train, than an
older dog from a rescue may

fit your bill, as well as
a pup of a breed that is
traditionally easier to train.

Intelligence is not necessarily
an indicator of
trainability.

Smart dogs often have their
own agenda and require

consistency on the part
of their owners.

Dogs with a willingness to work
and a desire to please

you often turn out to be
the best companions.

I recommend hiring a dog trainer
to perform a few tests

to help determine if the dog
is a good fit for you.

As a rule, terriers, hounds, and
Northern dogs are tough to

train because of their
intelligence and independent

natures, while sporting
and herding dogs
are easier to train.

The sharpest working obedience
breeds are Golden Retrievers,

Labrador Retrievers, Border
Collies, German Shepherds, and
Shetland Sheepdogs--

breeds that develop closely
with humans.

Some dogs enjoy lounging at
your feet to sleep the day

away, while others are very
energetic and ready to run a
marathon right alongside you.

Cute as they are, Basset Hounds,
Dachshunds, and Corgis
are not jogging companions.

And Airedales, German Shepherds,
and Border Collies

are not typical couch
potatoes.

All dogs need some exercise
to stay healthy.

Most adult dogs will not
exercise themselves, so time

for walks and other activities
is important.
Some dogs bark a lot.

And the amount can
vary by breed.

Terriers and scent hounds use
their voices to broadcast

their progress in
chasing prey.

Shelties and Collies bark
to tell the sheep to
get back to the barn.

Canaan dogs bark to alert
their families
of potential intruders.

Many dogs will bark if they're
bored, so owners should also

be sure to assess their own time
and ability for training,

walking, and play time, and
should properly confine the

dog when they can't otherwise
keep it from
disturbing the neighbors.

There are some special collars
available to deter a barking

dog, and training methods that
can help in some cases.

But if potential owners take
the noise factor into

consideration, problems are more
likely to be minimized.

Breed and temperament can be
described, but there's room

within that description
for individuality.

For example, Akitas are declared
to be tough, loyal,

aloof, dominant, aggressive to
other animals, and often
challenging.

However, many Akitas are sweet
and cuddly, love small

critters, will climb in laps if
allowed, and are anything
but aloof and dominant.

Terriers are scrappy, yappy,
tough and independent, but

Airedale Terriers bond very
closely to their humans and
are somewhat protective.

Hounds follow their eyes or
noses and are often oblivious
to human presence.

Dachshunds bond closely with
their families, and Greyhounds

and Whippets are sweet,
gentle pets.

Because temperament isn't always
easy to judge when

meeting a new dog, I strongly
recommend hiring or asking a

professional dog trainer to
come with you to evaluate
temperament.

They'll be able to assess a
dog's personality, compare it

with your wish list, and
determine what dog is the best
fit for you.

If you can't arrange this, ask
the people who have interacted

with the dog the most about
his temperament.

Once you've thought about the
commitment and have a good

idea of what type of dog is the
best fit for your family's

lifestyle, check out your local
animal shelter or animal

rescue to see if a
new addition is
waiting there for you.

I'm Kathy Santo for
Iams with Howdini.

I hope you found this helpful
as you welcome your new
addition into your family.

For more information on puppy
care and training, visit
iams.com/puppy.

title: How To Choose a Puppy: Tips on How to Pick a Puppy

comments.text:
Well 2-3 things for UR shepherd maybe it is a bit harder to handle because 
of the breed personality or it's probably just not understanding correct 
and UR probably not doing any better but I have 3 tips be patient, make 
sure if it's a family dog all family members know how to handle the doctors 
and try to get some help from neighbours + try to get as much tips and 
information as possible to reinforce all training sessions and one last 
thing sometimes pets can be not listening because they haven't had enough 
food for drink so if that is correct give ur shepherd some breaks to "heal" 
up and then try again, I really hope that worked out for u and its was 
helpful

comments.text:
Poodle do not shed but have to be groomed. Chinese Crested and Mexican 
Hairless are nearly Bald and can be baby wiped and have not body odor. They 
can not be left outside w/o sunscreen. Other hypoallergenic dogs that some 
people can tolerate are all sizes of the Greyhounds (there are 3 sizes) and 
Chihuahuas.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
If shedding is an issue maybe consider a Standard Poodle or a Whippet. 
Maybe you can look into adopting for a Rescue in your are for those 
specific breeds. If your sister can consider smaller breeds the Chinese 
Crested or Mexican Hairless is mostly bald and does not shed and can be 
baby wiped and has not body odor. Truly a gem! What they lack in beauty 
they make up for in maintenance.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Yes, even short coats do shed. Sometimes a lot! ;)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Love Pappillion's! Such a fun breed! ;)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Thank you for your honest feedback, not trying to come across negative just 
factual.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Such a great breed! ;)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Yes! They are smart, VERY active! MUST be walked on a leash b/c they are 
hunting type and will bolt w/o thinking so need to be leashed. My Bff has a 
pair that she breeds and every other year.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: What a tease! LOVE it! ;) What did you name him?
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
German Shepherds can be friends w/ proper training. It is ALL in the 
training. So keep that in mind! Personally my neighbor has 3 of them and I 
adore them. Great watch dog and very friendly to us! :) I know their 
different barks. They spent a lot of time training them. My children were 
raised with them too. If you like the size, Labs and Goldens are always a 
favorite as well.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Awww! ;)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Congratulations!
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
You may want to adopt an adult dog that already has an established 
personality. That may be your best bet. You may end up heart broken to get 
a puppy that does not meet your expectations. There are exceptions to every 
breed but generally speaking your criteria you may want to try looking at 
Italian Greyhound or Whippets.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Let's see, short hair, barks a lot, hmmm Chihuahua, Dachshund, Jack Russell 
Min Pincher...
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Please keep in mind that there are exceptions to every breed. Off the top 
of our heads Italian Greyhound's, Chinese Crested, Mexican Hairless, fit 
your dads bill. Have you thought about any of those? Have you thought about 
just visiting your friend's adoption center and just visiting and seeing if 
any of the pets are just the "right" one?
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
I an animal need to be alone for that many hours maybe considering 
something like fish is a better option. A dog or cat should not be brought 
into a home that would not have human companionship for that many hours. 
That would not be fair for so many reasons.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Sometimes a good ol' Heinz 57 can be the BEST companion and member of the 
family. Keep your ears open in case one is in need of a good home.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Rescue groups will have an idea of the temperament, how it interacts with 
other animals and w/ their family. Some breeds you may want to consider 
are...Border Collie, Italian Greyhound, Dachshund, Pug, or Cavalier King 
Charles Spaniel. Personally, I have had the sweetest, calmest and 
non-barking Chihuahua ever. Not the norm and I know we totally got lucky 
with her. Everyone wants her and they don't even like the breed. So hang in 
there, the right one will present itself.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
This is always a tough question b/c every breed has extremes and 
exceptions. However typically, Torkies tend to be rather hyper and 
yap-y.(Actually that is true of most toy breeds.) Were you looking 
specifically for a puppy? If U are then it will be very hard to determine 
the temperament until it is an adult.If U are willing to entertain a young 
adult then a visit to a local shelter may yield your perfect dog. Or U may 
want to consider looking for rescue groups for certain breeds in you area.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
So sorry! But U really need to listen to your parents. Dogs are a HUGE 
responsibility that can live for 12-22 years. There's puppy training, puppy 
Vet visits, spaying/neutering, Grooming, Flea Control, Heartworm 
prevention, good diet, and not 2 mention possible emergencies, or other 
costly issues like skin allergies, chronic eye/ear infections etc. Your 
parents are not trying 2B mean they just KNOW what it involved and they are 
not ready for that emotional, physical, and monetary expense.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Labs are usually very social and easy to adjust to a new member. Dachshunds 
are also usually friendly and easy going. Chihuahua can (not always) be a 
bit territorial and possessive. (Actually any breed can be like this)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
cont...Your parents are not trying to be mean they just do not want to have 
another pet (or they themselves) go through something like that again. Try 
to go easy on them. They really are stuck in the middle. Maybe you can 
visit more w/ friends who have pets. Or maybe you can volunteer at your Vet 
office or at a local shelter. Just a thought.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Sorry about your dog that had heartworms. So sad. As you now know, 
heartworms (and a bunch of other diseases) are totally preventable but you 
need regular exams, vaccines, bloodwork and preventative prescriptions. It 
gets really expensive and that is not to mention the grooming expenses and 
a good diet which can run up to $60 for a 35 pound bag. Keeping into 
considerations that emergencies can also happen. So with all that your 
parents really do know and are not yet ready for that yet.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
@howdiniguru my dad said I could get a pet but not soon. My mom said she's 
thinking about and if she agrees it's going to be in about 2 years :( she 
said she doesn't want one because my dog died of heart worms and there are 
a lot of Mosquitos here :( :( my brother said he was ok with getting one 
and got dissapointed when my mom said no. My brother wants a Pitbull, I 
want a chihuahua, my dad wasn't a beagle and my mom just shakes her head. I 
asked for a hamster and my mom and dad said no, I ask
comments.author: angrybirds957

comments.text:
cont. Grooming can get very expensive. Also a Chinese Crested does not 
shed, has not Body Odor nor has problems w/ fleas, but can have the same 
skin issues as humans including acne, dry/oily skin, sunburns (they need 
sunscreen if left outside for long periods of time) So, I know you really 
want one but again, your parents really need to agree. Maybe you can have 
them watch some of these videos w/U to show them that you are serious.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Because you are so young, your parents really NEED to be totally on board 
with getting a dog. They are a 15+ year commitment and a HUGE financial 
responsibility. If you are heart-set on a Chihuahua they can live to be up 
to 22+25 years (mine was 24 when she passed) As far a the shedding, short 
haired Chihuahua's are a fairly good choice. Also Greyhound (Italian 
Greyhounds are the smallest of the breed) shed very little and poodles 
don't shed at all but NEED to be groomed very frequently.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:

comments.text:
Not every breed gets "grumpy" when they get older. Actually it is rare that 
that happens. Some breeds are more prone to that. Also, if a dog (any 
breed) is in pain, it might appear to be "grumpy." There are so many 
wonderful breeds. Have you tried to visit a local shelter to adopt a small 
dog. There are so many that need a loving home. Usually you can find one 
that just "clicks" with you.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Unfortunately you can not prevent this. A lot is going to depend on the 
genetics of the Mother and Father. You will really need to research where a 
"Reputable" breeder is located and see if you can get a certificate of 
health for both the mother and father. Personally, my BFF has two Cavaliers 
and she had then Air Flighted to our state each one came from a different 
breeder to hopefully prevent possible inbreeding.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Labs are one of THE most popular breeds in the world. So you are in good 
company! :)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
In my family we get Labradors. They are just great dogs and we've always 
had one in the family. We had our first one, a black lab. Our next one was 
a chocolate lab named Chocolate, and our one that we have now, a yellow 
lab, named Elvis (long story why he's named that).

There is a bit. Is the Chihuahua aggressive already? If not you are off to 
a good start. you will have to be vigilant with the children. They will 
have to learn to respect and Leave him/her alone. I have successfully 
raised 3 children with several Chihuahuas. My girls love the dogs, and my 
dogs LOVE my girls. I know the kids will want to pick up and "play" with 
the dog but they do have to respect the dogs space.

Thanks for all the great comments! Make sure you check out the rest of our

comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
An extra little tip on puppies: Always try and figure out the breed of the 
dog you're getting, even if it's a mutt. I had a friend who got a pup who 
was the runt of her litter so they thought that she would really small. She 
ended up being a Great Dane mix and they had to give her up because she was 
too big and energetic. A good indicator of how big a puppy will grow is the 
size of it's paws, since they don't grow as much as the rest of the dog. 
Bigger paws = bigger dog.
comments.author: Gryffinclan

comments.text: Nice choice! :)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Any breed CAN work in an apartment if you are will to crate train, house 
break, and really exercise and work w/ him or her. If you neighbors will be 
a problem and not tolerate "obnoxious" behavior, maybe you can consider 
adopting a young adult with an established temperament and personality. 
There are so many that need a home and you might just be the right one to 
offer one. HTH
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: A Pomeranian perfect for apartments.
comments.author: Mij Beth

comments.text:

comments.text:
Thanks for watching! All of our puppies are rescues! So unfortunately we do 
not know their heritage. Although, that particular on looks like it might 
be a lab/retriever mix.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: Totally understand what you mean! :)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
All breeds have their pros and cons. Any breed w/ the name terrier usually 
means hyper (not always) small breeds tend to be more "cuddley" but can be 
hard to house break and can tend to be barkers. Large dogs need lost of 
exercise. I know this is not helping. Maybe you can adopt an adult (not old 
just not a puppy) That way you know its temperament and personality up 
front. Usually they are already fixed and current on vaccines. People move 
all the time and need home for their dogs.
comments.author: Howdini

I would caution against breeding her at all. Chihuahua often have a 
difficult time giving birth even when bred with other same sized 
Chihuahua's. Talk to your vet, but recommending spaying before their 1st 
heat cycle (5-6mos of age) is usually highly recommended. But again, talk 
to your vet.
comments.author: Howdini

rocky areas. Even with just little legs they are speed demons.

comments.text:
@AwesomeAnime1019 Whiteboxers are more often than not deaf. Breeders 
usually wouldn't suggest getting Whiteboxers, because about 50% of the time 
they are born deaf. Another 25% develop deafness over time, and only the 
last 25% don't get deaf. So you have a 75% chance of your new Whiteboxer 
being deaf. -,-
